title: The Samsung Incident
content:
A Samsung engineer had a bug.

So they did what any of us would do.

They pasted their source code into ChatGPT.

Then another engineer pasted confidential meeting notes.

Then another pasted proprietary test data.

Within 20 days, Samsung banned ChatGPT company-wide.

The kicker?

None of it was malicious.

They were just... trying to do their jobs faster.

That's the scary part.

Your biggest data leak risk isn't a rogue employee.

It's your most productive one.

#AISecurity #DataProtection #SecurityAwareness

title: The Google Search Console Leak
content:
November 2025.

ChatGPT conversations started appearing in Google Search Console.

Not summaries.
Not metadata.
Actual conversation logs.

Including:
‚Üí Relationship advice sessions (awkward)
‚Üí Medical questions (HIPAA?)
‚Üí Business strategy discussions (yikes)

OpenAI's response: "We're investigating."

Your board's question: "Is OUR data in there?"

The honest answer: "We have no way to know."

This is why "trust the AI company" is not a security strategy.

#AISecurity #DataPrivacy #CISO

title: 225,000 Credentials
content:
225,000 OpenAI credentials were found for sale on the dark web this year.

Not hacked from OpenAI directly.

Stolen from employees via infostealer malware.

Here's what that means:

Attackers now have access to:
‚Üí Full conversation histories
‚Üí Every file ever uploaded
‚Üí Every API key ever pasted
‚Üí Every "sensitive" prompt ever typed

Your employee's ChatGPT account is a treasure chest.

And most companies have no idea who's using what account.

67% of AI interactions happen on personal accounts.

Personal accounts = no SSO = no monitoring = no visibility.

When the CISO asks "who has access to our AI data"...

The answer is usually "we don't know."

That answer gets people fired.

#AISecurity #CISO #Compliance

title: Personal Accounts Blind Spot
content:
IT Security: "We monitor all AI usage."

Also IT Security: *can't see 67% of AI interactions because they're on personal accounts*

The personal account problem:

‚Üí Employee uses personal Gmail
‚Üí Signs into ChatGPT
‚Üí Pastes company source code
‚Üí Your DLP sees: "employee visited openai.com"
‚Üí What actually happened: trade secrets left the building

This is why JP Morgan banned ChatGPT.

This is why Goldman Sachs banned ChatGPT.

They couldn't see what their employees were sharing.

So they shut it down entirely.

The alternative: actually see what's being shared.

Even on personal accounts.
Even on personal devices.
Even when employees "forget" to use the approved tool.

Prohibition didn't work for alcohol.
It doesn't work for AI either.

#AISecurity #EnterpriseAI #CISO

title: The 92% Problem
content:
92% of Fortune 500 companies use ChatGPT.

54% of CISOs say generative AI poses a security risk.

So... 46% of CISOs are either:
a) Very confident in their controls
b) Not paying attention
c) About to have a bad quarter

I've talked to dozens of security leaders.

Zero of them said "we have this completely figured out."

Most said some version of:

"We know there's risk. We're trying to quantify it. Our employees are moving faster than our policies."

That's the real state of enterprise AI security in 2026.

Not "solved."
Not "ignored."

Somewhere in between, hoping nothing makes the news.

#AISecurity #CISO #EnterpriseRisk

title: Training Is Not Enough
content:
"We trained our employees on AI security."

Great.

Did you know:

‚Üí 77% of AI interactions still involve company data
‚Üí Even after security awareness training
‚Üí Even after signing acceptable use policies
‚Üí Even after the all-hands meeting with the scary slides

Training tells people what NOT to do.

It doesn't stop them from doing it at 11pm when they're trying to hit a deadline.

Your most compliant employee will paste an API key into ChatGPT when they're stuck on a bug at midnight.

Not because they forgot the training.

Because the training said "be careful" and they thought they were.

Training + monitoring = security.

Training alone = compliance theater.

#AISecurity #SecurityAwareness #ComplianceManagement

title: The Slack Screenshot
content:
True story from a CISO friend:

Their security team found a Slack message.

An engineer had posted a screenshot.

The screenshot showed ChatGPT.

The ChatGPT prompt contained their AWS production credentials.

The engineer was asking for help with a Lambda function.

The screenshot was in a public Slack channel.

With 400+ people.

And Slack's default retention setting.

And automated backups to their data lake.

So now those credentials exist in:
‚Üí ChatGPT's systems
‚Üí Slack's systems
‚Üí Their data lake
‚Üí Their backup systems
‚Üí 400 people's screenshot caches

From one person trying to debug a function.

This is why we can't have nice things.

(They rotated the credentials. After I reminded them.)

#AISecurity #DevSecOps #SecurityAwareness

title: The Audit Question
content:
Auditor: "Can you show me your AI acceptable use policy?"

CISO: *produces beautifully formatted 12-page PDF*

Auditor: "Great. Can you show me how you enforce it?"

CISO: "We... trust our employees to follow it."

Auditor: "Can you show me audit logs of AI data flows?"

CISO: "We don't have those."

Auditor: "Can you demonstrate that sensitive data isn't being shared with AI?"

CISO: "Not exactly."

Auditor: "So you have a policy that you can't enforce or verify?"

CISO: "It's a really nice PDF though."

[This is how SOC 2 findings happen.]

#Compliance #SOC2 #CISO

title: What CISOs Say Privately
content:
What CISOs say in public:
"We have robust controls around AI usage."

What CISOs say privately:
"We have no idea what's being shared. We're terrified. Please don't quote me."

I've had this exact conversation 20+ times this year.

The gap between public confidence and private concern is massive.

Why?

‚Üí They can't admit uncertainty to the board
‚Üí They can't ban AI (business won't allow it)
‚Üí They can't monitor personal accounts (technically hard)
‚Üí They can't train their way out (employees forget)

So they do what they can: policy, prayer, and hoping.

The ones who sleep well at night?

They've deployed technical controls that work regardless of employee behavior.

That's the difference between "hoping" and "knowing."
